awd_titl_txt: Workshop to meet the grand challenges in quantum fluids and solids
awd_abstract_narration: This workshop will bring together researchers from around the world to identify the "Grand Challenge" questions that can be addressed through studies of Quantum Fluids and Solids.  Past studies in this area have brought forth new phenomena, such as many different forms of superfluidity, as well as serving as a testing ground for new ideas in condensed matter physics, such as the renormalization group.  This workshop, which will take place as a satellite meeting to the 2015 International Conference on Quantum Fluids and Solids, will offer the opportunity for researchers in the quantum fluids and solids community as well as from related disciplines to identify the grand challenge problems where the study of quantum fluids and solids can contribute.  It will also provide an opportunity for graduate students, postdocs and young faculty to interact with more senior researchers.  The results of the workshop will be published in a leading peer reviewed journal.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
A workshop, entitled " Grand Challenges in Quantum Fluids and Solids" was organized and took place from August 7 to August 9, 2015 on the campus of the University at Buffalo, at Amherst, N.Y. The Steering Committee consists of Frank Gasparini ( Buffalo), Bill Halperin ( Northwestern), Eckhard Krotschect ( Buffalo), Yoonseok Lee ( Univ. of Florida), Jeevak Parpia ( Cornell) and Moses Chan. There were a total of 68 'multi-generation' particpants attending the Workshop. The participants include three Nobel lureates as well as 18 post-docs and graduate students. Participants came from US, Canada, UK, France, Germany, Russia, Japan, Korea and China.

The Workshop was organized as five half-day sessions: (I) Superfluid helium and quantum gas as model system for quantum information and quantum computation (II) One and two dimensional helium systems (III) Quantum turbulence and emergent phenomena (IV) Superfluid He-3 and (V) Roadmap to meet the grand challenges. Each of the five sessions were further divided into two or three focused topics. A docent and two or three speakers were appointed for each focused topic. Since the main purpose of the workshop is to promote discussion among all the participants, the docents and the speakers were tasked specifically to introduce rather than to lecture upon the subject. The docents were successful in encouraging the participants in joining in the discussions and roughly half of the time of each sessions were devoted to open forum.

A number of topics spawn a great dealof discussions, these topics include electrons on helium surfaces as a means of quantum computation, new quantum spin liquid state in 2D He-3 ; fountain effect driven mass flow through solid He-4 and possible evidence of Majorana Fermion in superfluid He-3. These topics will inspire new experimental and theoretical investigations.

The last session of the Workshop was devoted to define a roadmap to raise interest in the study of Quantum Fluids and Solids (QFS). A number of ideas were brought up, including offering graduate courses  in QFS to acquaint physics graduate students on the beauty of the subject, broadens the QFS sumposia and conferences to include topics in condensed matter physics with intellectual overlap with QFS such as heavy Fermion, topological superconductors and quantum computation. Attempts have been made in this direction, but  it will be useful to be more pro-active in the future. It was also suggested that our students should be encouraged to broadened their physics and technical expertise. 

An open access web site of the workshop ( sites.psu.edu/qfs2015) is maintained and stay available into the foreseeable future for all to visit. The participant list, the program and slides of the majority of talks in pdf format as well as photos of workshop are available on the web site. 

Moses Chan, Bill Halperin and Keith Schwab ( Caltech) three participants of the workshop wereinvited to make presentation at the October 6, 2015 meeting of the Condensed Matter Materials Physics Research Committee (CMMRC) of the National Academy of Sciences.The meeting was convened to have the CMMRC members, together with program managers in funding agencies to explore the current status of and issues faced by the QFS and exciton physics ( represented by Davis Snoke of the Univ.of Pittsburgh).
